fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1938].
  {panel}

Service Desk plugin has a number of screens but those screens does not have a context. As a result, other plugins cannot attach anything to those views like the portal page (servicedesk/customer/portal/XYZ). 
So, it will be useful to introduce a new web resource context for a portal page.


If your plugin adds a number of screens to the application, you may find it useful to introduce a new web resource context for your plugin that your plugin web resources (or any other plugin web resource) can hook into, to be automatically included on these screens.
To introduce a new context in your plugin Velocity templates, you can call the requireResourcesForContext() method on the WebResourceManager object from your Velocity templates:

$webResourceManager.requireResourcesForContext("com.acme.plugin.fancy-context")

This will include any resource in the page that specifies a context like this in its definition: <context>com.acme.plugin.fancy-context</context>.
fields.summary: Introduce new context for web-resourse

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1937].
{panel}
{panel:title=Atlassian update as of 17th May 2017}
{panel}
Hi all,

We've recently made it possible to add multiple languages for your portal and have resolved this issue for JIRA Service Desk Cloud.

Check out the new "Language Support" section to manage translations for both the customer portal and email notifications. Read more about it [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskcloud/blog/2017/05/translate-your-customer-portal]. 

Thanks again for your help in tackling this problem.

Cheers,

JIRA Service Desk Team

 
{panel:title=Atlassian update as of 16th November 2016}
{panel}
Hi all,

Thanks for all your comments. There's certainly strong interest behind this.

We would love to hear more from you on how your team shall add and maintain multiple languages on the portal. Understanding this will help us make the right thing that fits your needs perfectly.

If you would like to help out, please take 2 minutes to answer these questions - [https://jsd-beta.typeform.com/to/VS5QKT].

Cheers,
JIRA Service Desk Team

 
----
h3. Summary

If a JIRA Service Desk is created while the Default Language is set to a certain language, the customer portal will keep this language for the _workflow step_ and _why do you need this?_ text on the customer portal even after changing it to a different language.
h3. Environment

I have tested this behavior with the following:
 * JIRA 6.4.5
 * JIRA Service Desk 2.4.2

 * JIRA Service Desk-2.5.0-OD-02-002-D20150506T043445-language-pack-de_DE.jar
 * JIRA Service Desk-2.5.0-OD-02-002-D20150506T043445-language-pack-es_ES.jar

 * JIRA-6.4.5-language-pack-de_DE.jar
 * JIRA-6.4.5-language-pack-es_ES.jar

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install the German (de_DE) language pack files for JIRA and JIRA Service Desk on your test instance.
 # Change Default language to _Deutsch (Deutschland)_
 # Create a new JIRA Service Desk
 # Create an issue
 # Install the Spanish (es_ES) language pack files for JIRA and JIRA Service Desk on your test instance.
 # Change Default language to _español (España)_
 # Go to the customer portal
 # Go to _My Requests_
 # Click on the issue you had created earlier

h3. Expected Results

The expected result would be that the Customer Portal translates all the fields according to the selected language.
h3. Actual Results

The customer portal keeps the translations of the language it was created in for the following:
 * _Workflow Step_
 * _Why do you need this?_ text
 !not_changed.png|thumbnail!

h3. Notes
 * If this is done with a language that does not have all the values translated those texts will also show up in the language the Service Desk was created in.
 * This issue occurs when the user profile language is different from the one the JIRA Service Desk was created in.
 * Even if the system default language is in english, and the user profile language is Spanish, these two pieces of text still are presented in German.
 * I have also verified that these 2 missing pieces of text are in fact present in bot the Spanish and German language pack:
 !PACK2.png|thumbnail!

h3. Workaround

Create the JIRA Service Desk in the language that you intend to use it in.
 (this might present a problem if the user profile language differs per user)
fields.summary: Changing the system language in JIRA does not translate everything on a Service Desk portal.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1924].
{panel}
Currently, the Email processor from under the Global Mail Settings will filter out:
 * auto-replied emails
 * mails marked as spam
 * delivery status notifications
 * emails originating from a JIRA instance

In certain situations, automatically generated emails from alarm systems or automatically forwarded emails, can have a different value than "no" set for the Auto-Submitted header of the email.
This will cause the email to get filtered out and not get further processed.
The AutoReplyMailFilter filter will prevent these kind of emails from creating issues in Service Desk.

Please provide an option to white-list email addresses to prevent them from being discarded as invalid emails under the Service Desk Email settings.
Alternatively, provide an option to disable any of the above mentioned mail filters from the Service Desk Email settings section

*WORKAROUND*

JSD has [public API|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/service-desk/rest/]
Issues can be created via [POST /rest/servicedeskapi/request|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/service-desk/rest/#api-request-post]
For more details you can read [a tutorial|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/service-desk/exploring-the-jira-service-desk-domain-model-via-the-rest-apis/]

{panel:title=Update as of 5th Aug, 2019}
Hi Everyone,

Thank you for your patience with a much requested feature.

We have launched the ability to add trusted email domains to a permitted list which will ensure that emails coming from those domains are never filtered out. The notes on managing the permitted list can be found [here|https://support.atlassian.com/jira-service-desk-cloud/docs/receive-requests-from-an-email-address] . In particular, the steps to add an email domain to the permitted list can be found [here|https://support.atlassian.com/jira-service-desk-cloud/docs/how-are-domains-added-to-the-permitted-list].
 {panel}
fields.summary: To provide incoming white-list email address function for email marked as bulk / jira / spam

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1917].
  {panel}

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Create a Service Desk project.
# Edit the workflow that's generated and change all the transitions to global ones (in the workflow editor, select each transition and tick "Allow all statuses to transition to this one").
# Remove all the exisiting local transitions (the ones explicitly going from one status to another, e.g. "Waiting for Support" to "Waiting for Customer").
# Add a comment that should trigger an automation rule to change the issue status.

h3. Expected results
The issue is transitioned into the correct status.

h3. Actual results
The issue isn't transitioned, and the audit logs report "Action does not exist for current issue status".
fields.summary: Automation rules to change issue statuses fail to trigger if the transition is global instead of local

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1916].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
At the moment, only comments made in the Customer Portal view are recognised as coming from the customer. This means, for example, that automation rules can only be triggered from there.

The Reporter may have access to the same issue in base JIRA view (if they have Collaborator permissions), but at an attempt to comment there, they'll see a warning:
{quote}Your comment will only be visible to agents and collaborators{quote}  


- This is in accordance with the Service Desk logic, but can be confusing: users wouldn't expect completely different behaviour when accessing the same ticket in two different parts of the application.
- Teams that work with internal requesters don't always want to use the Customer Portal. For users that are used to JIRA views, this adds additional overhead of having navigate to Customer Portal in order to add a comment.

h3. Suggested Solution
In the JIRA view, reporters should have an option to add a comment as a Service Desk customer.
fields.summary: Allow Reporters to Comment as Customers in Base JIRA Views
Use Project URL in Notification Emails

Hi,

we work alot with components in our projects. Based on a component an issue would appear on an agile dashboard or not.

When we receive a request in our servicedesk it would be nice to set a component based on issuetype.

E.g. on the servicedesk portal an employee fill out a request for a problem. This would get issuetype "bug" based on the request type. 

With the Automation we would like to be able to build such a trigger:

When: issue = created If: issuetype = bug Then: component = bug

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1899].
  {panel}

I modified the permission scheme of my JIRA Service Desk so that Customers and Service Desk Agents *CANNOT* delete issues.  Doing so results in a warning stating that the "_service desk project may not work as expected_".

This warning should not appear at all based on the minor permission scheme changes I made. My IT department does not believe that customers nor service desk agents should have permission to delete service desk issues.  Only service desk administrators should have this privilege.

I ended up reverting back to the original permission scheme because I was receiving too many emails from my service desk agents informing me of the warning they're getting.

Please fix JIRA Service Desk so that a warning is *NOT* given when we make justifiable changes to the permission scheme.
fields.summary: Modification of permission scheme should not result in warning

  {panel}

We need the ability to pause an SLA until a day or for the next 2 days (48 hours). After this time is over the SLA should run again without any actions taken from a user.
Example:
SLA to get in contact with customer: 4h
Ticket is created and SLA runs to 3:45 h
I call the customer, but he is not available for the next 2 days.
I want to have a field (pause sla for) where I type "48 hours".
48 hours later the SLA should run on from 3:45 h.
fields.summary: Pause SLA until Day X

Creating an option to auto-assign these messages to an existing user/customer would ensure potentially valid requests from users that are not yet registered are not lost in the ether.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1887].
  {panel}

h3. ***Summary***
When trying to add a holiday in the SLA Calendar by using Firefox and IE, it will return an error. Service Desk also does not recognize French months in the date.

h3. ***Steps to Reproduce 1***
# Set the default language and profile language in JIRA to French
# Go to Service Desk 
# Create a new SLA Calendar
# Add any holiday
# Service Desk will throw an error: {color:red}{{Invalid Date Format}}{color}
!Screen Shot 2015-05-15 at 2.50.31 AM.png|thumbnail!

h3. ***Steps to Reproduce 2***
# Go to Service Desk by using Firefox or IE11
# Create a new SLA Calendar
# Add any date holiday
# Service Desk will throw an error: {color:red}{{Invalid Date Format}}{color}
!Screen Shot 2015-05-15 at 2.50.31 AM.png|thumbnail!

h3. ***Workaround***
# Configure the holiday by using Chrome.
# Change the profile language to English
# Add the holiday in the SLA Calendar
fields.summary: Service Desk SLA Calendar cannot create holiday in Firefox and IE11. This issue also happened when we change the language to French

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, on the customer portal login screen, the option to login using either Google Apps or Service Desk / JIRA credentials is present. This can lead to confusion for service desk portal customers, as they might believe that they are able to log in using google credentials (which only service desk agents can use that option), and that will not work.

h3. Suggested Solution
I believe we should remove Google Apps log in from the customer portal log in screen.

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1881].
  {panel}

For a proper major incident management we want to escalate the incident to people outside of the service desk team. We'd like to add them as Watchers to the incident whenever there is a critical or blocking incident and notify them on certain events (Issue Created, Issue Updated, Issue Assigned, etc.)

The current automation functionality considers only (Issue Created, Commented) and allows only "Mention" as action. This is not enough and the mention functionality is not reliable enough.

Suggestion:
- Allow all JIRA System Event Types as "WHEN" in the Automation Rule
- Allow to Set Watchers as "@ Alert user".

h3. Workaround

The workaround involves creating the statuses in the JIRA Administration interface and then changing the status ID to be the ID of the deleted status. You only need to add the status and change the ID, the status does not need to be added to any workflows.

# Use the following query to obtain the ID and status name that is missing
{noformat}
SELECT DISTINCT newvalue,newstring FROM changeitem WHERE field ='status' AND newvalue NOT IN (SELECT id FROM issuestatus);
{noformat}
** If more than one status is returned, perform the following steps for each unique "newvalue"
*** The string is the status name. if multiple strings appear for the same "newvalue" you should select whichever name suits you best. You only need to create one status for each unique "newvalue"
# Create the status in the JIRA Administration page
# After creating the status, hover over the edit link for the new status to obtain the URL for this link. Copy down the ID that appears at the end of this URL.
# Shut down JIRA
# Update the issuestatus table so that the newly created status has the ID of the deleted status. 
** Run the following query. Replace the first ID with the ID you obtained from the URL when you added the status. Replace the second ID with the missing status ID that you obtained in the first SQL query.
{noformat}
UPDATE issuestatus SET id='10200' WHERE id='10610';
{noformat}
# Start JIRA
fields.summary: Deleted status causes 500 error NullPointerException in customer portal

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1876].
  {panel}

In a public SD, emails are rejects if the email address doesn't belong to any users and the emails subject contains the key of an existent issue in that SD. The user is not created either.

In this public SD, if the user doesn't exist, it should be created. It is in fact created if the subject doesn't contain a issue key, but fails when it has an existent key.

The follow error appears in the processing logs:
{noformat}
Unable to get user.
{noformat}
!error.png|thumbnail!

For some reason, this error is respecting the system language (though others don't) and in Spanish, the error is:
{noformat}
No se puede obtener usuario.
{noformat}

Not test in other languages.

*Steps to Reproduce*
# Create SD
# Select options 'Everyone with an account can access my Customer Portal' and 'Anyone can sign up for a customer account on my Customer Portal' to have a public SD
#* This should allow automatic user creation when emails are received from address not used by existent users, as per [this documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/SERVICEDESKCLOUD/Configuring+public+signup]
# Enable email requests
# Create issue, say ABC-1
# From an email address not used by any user in JIRA, send an email to the SD where the emails subject contains ABC-1 and the email body is not empty

*Expected Behavior*
# User is created using the email address, as per the documentation
# If existent issue cannot be commented, new issue is create with the subject as summary

*Actual Outcome*
# User is not created
# No issues are commented or created
# The error appears in the logs

*Alternative Behavior*

To have a more verbose information about what has failed in the Email Settings' Audit Log, this at least give a better context to the administrator and without going through all the trouble to find out what is the issue behind this.

Suggested error message:
{noformat}
Email found to be created as {{issue key}}, and user {{username}} has no permission to comment on {{issue key}}
{noformat}
fields.summary: Service Desk Rejects Emails for Non-existent User in Public SD

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1875].
  {panel}

As a SD admin, I want to provide my different clients with their own SLA reports from within the same SD.

We use a single ServiceDesk for about 50 clients, and maintain the same set of SLA rules (calendar, resolve times, ...) for all, as we run it with the same group of people. However, my clients are independent companies and as such each want a quarterly SLA report based on how we did for their own issues. e.g. 45 clients whose metrics would fall into the SLA specs, while 5 having SLA violations that quarter.

For this I would need a way of easily grouping the individual customer-accounts into clients, so I could introduce a JQL for each of the reports filtering on the client (reporter in membersOf("client"). Or a grouping on emaildomains could also fit the bill (reporter_email in ("@client.com", "@client.co.uk", "@client.net"))

Our users are typically entered by ourselves (no self-registration).

Apparently users-groups have been switched off for SD customers as this did not match the licensing policy.
fields.summary: Allow SLA reporting against separate Service Desk customer groups.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1874].
  {panel}

As a support team member I am looking for a solution to serve our internal and especially our external customers.

I have set up your cloud solution Service Desk. I have read documentation, faqs, googled etc. but my three days experience does not pull out an answer to my questions.

I want external customers to have possibility to send and receive email to/from system. So far I haven't figured out how to get emails going to (again external)customers from our pre-defined email address sent by Jira SD system. Incoming mail works as expected. There's no option to configure outgoing mail server. Why? 

I do not care what is the way to solve this inside your cloud but it is a show stopper for us if it is not possible.

Best Regards,

Kimmo Häyrinen
fields.summary: External customers and outgoing (SMTP) mail configuration in cloud

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1873].
  {panel}

h3. Current Behaviour
* If a *Collaborator* is added as *Request Participant*, the *Collaborator* will not receive notification for *Internal Comments*

h3. Feature Request
* *Collaborator* should still receive notification for *Internal Comments* even if he is added as *Request Participant* on a ticket
fields.summary: Notification on Internal Comments to Collaborators added as Request Participant

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1872].
  {panel}

h3. Steps to reproduce:
*JIRA Cloud*
1. https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/service-desk
2. 'try it for free'
3. (stick with the default cloud trial products: JIRA, JIRA Service Desk)
4. enter your details, 'start trial'
5. receive email about your newly created instance
6. attempt to log in to your newly created instance

*JIRA Server*
Tested on JIRA 6.4.4 and JIRA Service Desk 2.4.2:
# Install JIRA with JSD.
# Apply an evaluation license to JIRA Service Desk.
# Create a new user with the "JIRA Users" Global Permission.
# Try to login with the newly added user.

h3. Result:
* 302 redirect to http://rit-jsdlabs.atlassian.net/secure/MyJiraHome.jspa
* 302 redirect to http://rit-jsdlabs.atlassian.net/servicedesk/agent/onboarding
* 302 redirect to http://rit-jsdlabs.atlassian.net/secure/MyJiraHome.jspa
* 302 redirect to http://rit-jsdlabs.atlassian.net/servicedesk/agent/onboarding
.... (redirect loop)

[~vwong] claims he set up 5 instances this way, and saw it reproduce with 1 of them ({{rit-jsdlabs.atlassian.net}}.)

h3. Workaround
*JIRA Cloud*
This doesn't seem to happen to every user, but you can still get to User admin even though there is a redirect loop by going to <instance>/admin.  Add the user to the Service Desk Agents group, and go back to JIRA.  The pages should load, now.  You can then remove the user from the Service Desk Agents group.

*JIRA Server*
Apparently, this bug only affects users during their first login. 
If this problem is affecting all users (including the JIRA System Administrator), follow the steps below:
# Stop JIRA.
# Remove the JIRA Service Desk OBR plugin file from the {{$JIRA_HOME/plugins/installed-plugins}} folder.
# Start JIRA.
# Login to JIRA and install the JIRA Service Desk plugin again.

If an administrator already has access to the instance, follow the steps below:
# Login as a JIRA System Administrator.
# Go to *Cog Icon > Add-ons > JIRA Service Desk*.
# Expand the list of modules (e.g. * 244 of 244 modules enabled*).
# Find the *sdOnboardingFlow* module and click on *Disable*.
fields.summary: New JIRA Users get stuck in a redirect loop due to JSD onboarding

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1871].
  {panel}

On a ticket type we have, I am only able to create "Internal Comments", which are labeled with a red lock and "Your comment will only be visible to agents and collaborators":
!jira-internal-comment.png|thumbnail!

On such comments,

* {color:#8eb021}(works){color} If I submit them by clicking the "Add internal comment" button, the comment gets submitted as expected...
* {color:#d04437}(bug){color} ... but if I use Ctrl+Enter to submit the comment (similarly to many other forms in JIRA), the form disappears just as if it was captured properly, but the comment isn't submitted. I see that the button tooltip mentions Alt+S as the keyboard shortcut; ignoring Ctrl+Enter sounds legit then, but JIRA shouldn't glob my shortcut and discard my comment.
fields.summary: Internal Comments posted with Ctrl+Enter discard the comment and silently close the form

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1870].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

When using the project sidebar in IE11, issue details on the left side are missing from the navigation bar.
It also causes the issue transition screen to freeze after clicking on the transition.

h3. Environment

The only occurs on IE11.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

I reproduced this bug on atlassian_jira_6_4_branch (6.4.2). You need to install service desk plugin in order to reproduce it. 

# Start JIRA instance and install service desk plugin
# Create a service desk project and create several issues 
# Launch IE11
# Press {{F12}} to launch F12 - the IE dev toolkit
# Click {{Issues}} -> {{Search for issues}}
# Select first issue
# Select any other issue
# Resume debugger via {{F8}} if it is paused
# Notice that the selected issue is successfully selected
# Select yet another issue

h3. Expected Results
The details of the issue selected in step #7 should be rendered.
No unhandled exceptions.

h3. Actual Results
The details of the issue selected in step #4 is rendered.
An unhandled exception after step #4: {{Unable to get property 'removeChild' of undefined or null reference}} at a {{j.parentNode.removeChild(j)}} from {{batch.js:149:394}}
Like in attachment !Screen Shot 2015-04-15 at 6.14.02 PM.png|thumbnail!  SDP-3 is selected but content for SDP-4 is displayed.

I'm able to reproduce this issue always but sometimes for whatever reason IE is not showing this error in console, if that happens to you, restart the browser.

*Update 140515*: It seems to affect transition returning the same error as well. !Screen Shot 2015-05-14 at 8.11.59 PM.png|thumbnail!

If not able to reproduce try disable reloadable plugin resources (just for jmake).
fields.summary: Unable to get property 'removeChild' content in IE11

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1857].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
When an _issue_updated_ webhook event is triggered by an action in Customer Portal, the posted JSON misses the 'changelog' node.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a webhook to be triggered at 'Issue updated' event, and with a JQL covering a project with Service Desk enabled. 
# In Customer Portal view of an issue covered by the webhook's JQL, add an attachment, with or without a comment.
# Observe the JSON posted at the issue update.

h3. Expected Results
The POST body includes the 'changelog' node with the information about new attachment:
{code}"changelog": {
    "id": "11111",
    "items": [
      {
        "field": "Attachment",
        "fieldtype": "jira",
        "from": null,
        "fromString": null,
        "to": "11111",
        "toString": "image.png"
      }{code}

h3. Actual Results
The POST is missing the 'changelog' details, only the information about the new comment is distinguished. 
They 'changelog' information is only included in POSTs triggered by actions in JIRA Issue View or Service Desk agent views.
 
h3. Notes
To see the details of Webhooks posts in JIRA logs: in *JIRA Admin > System > Logging & Profiling* add the package _com.atlassian.webhooks_ witht the DEBUG level of logging.
fields.summary: Webhook POST Triggered from Customer Portal Doesn't Include 'changelog' Node

h3. Current SLA Metrics Order
The metrics is classified to two categories, the upper one is the metrics where the time is still counting while the lower one has the time stop counting.
Each category will have the arrangement according the duration goal of the metric (shortest goal duration will be on top) then followed by the alphabetical arrangement. 

h3. Feature Request
Customer would like to have the feature to order the SLA metrics in issue view base on their process flow.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1855].
  {panel}

A customer needing support is often a member of a larger team, all of who need to be kept informed regarding progress of an issue. This could be supported by:

* Maintaining a record of all email addresses which were on cc when the issue was created by an incoming email (from the known customer contact who has an account)
* Any that already have accounts can be added as watchers, the remaining ones are recorded in the database.
* If subsequent incoming emails on that issue have additional addresses added, the system notices this and adds them to the cc list
* The Service Desk admin can see and edit the cc list to e.g. remove unwanted addresses.

This will work well for the customer, who is then able to use Outlook as their main method of communication with both the internal team and the external subcontractor.

It also avoids unnecessary work adding loads of extra registered users when they really just wanted to be on a cc list, or maintaining email aliases.

I believe I am seeing requests that would be covered by this functionality in both https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSD-1593 and https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSD-960.

It looks like pretty simple functionality to me, so I hope it can soon be included.
fields.summary: Create and maintain external cc-list from email communication

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1851].
  {panel}

We use an external user directory (AD) for all of our users. The only internal user is the built in JIRA administrator.

Having the password reset link misleads customers because they think they can reset their passwords even though they can't. Upon submitting the link with their external user name, they do not get a message stating that it's not possible; they instead get an email telling them that password reset is disabled.

If I turn on External User Management, the link is still there, but then it shows a message. I would like to be able to create a few groups locally, so I don't really want this option to be on.

I would rather not present a password reset link to users at all.
fields.summary: Password reset link should be optional

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1846].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Documentation for writing your own automation rule components|bgColor=#f5f5f5}
If you would like to write your own components, please visit the documentation here: https://developer.atlassian.com/display/JIRADEV/Automation+Rule+Components
{panel}

*Original description*
We use Service Desk for a number of different projects and built our own set of Automation rules using the JIRA automation plugin: https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.plugin.automation.jira-automation-plugin

We have a number of automated jobs that trigger based on a JQL Filter and are executed using a CRON schedule.

We use these rules for:
* Automatically commenting on inactive tickets waiting for customer information. 
* Automatically closing inactive tickets.
* Automatically transitioning tickets based on a date field that is set in the request.
etc

Having JQL triggers for SD Automation would (hopefully) mean that we could retire our other automation system and move to using the built-in tools exclusively, which would be great :)
fields.summary: Service Desk Automation should allow JQL Triggers for 'IF', with schedule options

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1834].
  {panel}

We set up service desks for our clients, and we often require them to have read-access to documentation for their specific projects, which we are not able to make publicly available.

They have an account in ServiceDesk (and I've even tried adding them to a group in Jira), however if we assign the group to the space in Confluence with view access they don't have access to the resources - presumably because they are a 'customer' usergroup instead of an agent.

Unfortunately the only option we have right now is to email these customers PDF's of their documentation pages, meeting notes, etc which is really inefficient and clunky.

It would make sense if the customer was allowed restricted access - e.g read and comment - to the confluence spaces based on their access & honouring the labels set up on ServiceDesk.
fields.summary: Enable user accounts on Servicedesk to access restricted content on Confluence

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1833].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition

JSD Customer Portal can be configured to be made available for Public Sign Up. Any customer who knows the URL to the Customer Portal can then sign up via the portal and then they will be able to raise a ticket.  There is no notification that goes out to the Agents to let them know that a new customer has signed up.

While an agent can see the list of the Customers on the Customer list, they would not know when a new customer is creating an account.

h3. Suggested Solution

It would be great if there was a notification that will let the agents know when there is a new customer sign up on the portal.
fields.summary: Notification to Agent when a Customer Sign Up

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1832].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, SLA goals needs to be predefined and it's static. In some cases, we need to make it flexible.
h3. Suggested Solution
Make SLA goals to be dynamic.
Eg: SLA goal can be set based on a custom date field.

h3. Why this is important
* This is needed to make sure the report is accurate
** Example: SLA is breached before the due date and this is definitely not the right statistics for the high level management


{panel:title=Original request}
My issue over here is that I have a date type custom field on JSD customer portal. I need to link my SLA with this Date chosen be the customer. For example deadline SLA should be in sync with the date provided by customer, for every request I will be having different deadline, so constant deadline SLA is not making sense to us at present, Is there any way we can achieve this ?
{panel}
fields.summary: Dynamic SLA Goal in JSD

  {panel}

h3.Problem Definiton

Having mail handler of JSD not listed in JIRA makes it difficult and confusing for admins to check all the mail handlers. Also, some users create ServiceDesk mail handlers in JIRA core side which can cause issues.

h3. Suggested Solution
We need to have all mail handlers including Service Desk in one page to have better view of incoming mail handlers.
Otherwise to check for Service Desk mail handlers we need to check every Service Desk project Email Setting separately which makes troubleshooting difficult.
However, since Service Desk mail handler is independent from JIRA core, it is good to JUST show the mail handler at Incoming Mail page, but user won't be able to edit SD mail handler or CREATE Service Desk mail handler which makes duplication and leave it as read only.
fields.summary: Having All Mail Handlers Listed at Incoming Mail Page

h3. Problem Definition

Configuring a Service Desk and would like to Bulk Add New Customers via CSV or other External File. Not having an import method like this is a problem for Service Desk users that have an existing customer base configured in another system but are moving towards JIRA Service Desk.
h3. Suggested Solution

Add an option to Import Customers into a Service Desk Project similar to a User/Group Import via CSV
h3. Workaround
 - New Customers can be created manually
 -- Use the Invite Customers Link and specify each Email Address for New Customers (space delimited for multiple addresses; eg {{email1@domain.com email2@domain.com etc}})
 - Each Customer can self-register to access the Service Desk (if configured for self sign-up)
 - Create a customer via [REST API|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/service-desk/rest/#api-rest-servicedeskapi-customer-post]

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1818].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
Customers are no longer able to view Customer Portal or their reported issues if the Service Desk Customer - Portal Access security type is not granted Create Issues permission in the Permission Scheme.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Service Desk with default settings.
# Add a few customers to the Service Desk, and let them create a few issues in the Customer Portal
# Edit the Service Desk project's permission scheme so that "Service Desk Customer - Portal Access" security type is removed from the Create Issues permission.

h3. Expected Results
Customers can no longer create new issues, but can still see existing issues they have reported.

h3. Actual Results
* Customer portal disappears from help center list when viewed by customer.
* Customers can no longer see their previously reported open issues in the Customer Portal. Ofcourse as expected they are also unable to create new requests.
* My Requests section in Customer Portal doesn't show any issues reported by the Customer.

h3. Notes
Strangely, the customer will still be able to see those issues by accessing the URL directly
fields.summary: Removing the 'Service Desk Customer - Portal Access' from Create Issues permission prevents customers from viewing issues they reported

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, JIRA Service Desk supports only a single e-mail account and consequently a single Request Type to be created via e-mail (see [Setting up the email channel|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/SERVICEDESK/Setting+up+the+email+channel]).

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be great to support multiple e-mail accounts for a single service desk so that each account can be configured for a different request type.
 
h3. Workaround 
There is currently no workaround for using multiple request types for the e-mail channel.

  {panel}

At the moment, the automation allows an issue to automatically be transitioned upon a comment. However, if a custom workflow is being used, the available options does not allow the issue to transition to a specific transition. Example

There is custom workflow, with custom statuses to represent 2 different 'work groups':

1) Waiting for Support
2) Waiting for Tech Support

Both of the above statuses can transition to the status 'Waiting for Customer'

When the Customer comments, the issue should transition to the most recent status just before this.
